pullRequest.title: Kv symmetric key support
pullRequest.bodyText: Enables Local Key support for AsyncKEK and KEK.

commit.message: making key fetch logic thread safe

nodes.bodyText: Shouldn't you be asserting the UNWRAP_KEY permission?
Nit: here and the line below spends time negating, which slows things down a little but also makes readability more difficult. Could maybe be simplified.
Should this maybe be setKey? Not sure if that's idiomatic, but I thought normally setting objects uses the "set" prefix.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -299,4 +300,18 @@ public CryptographyClientBuilder serviceVersion(CryptographyServiceVersion versi this.version = version; return this; } + + /** + * Sets the jsonWebKey to be used for cryptography operations. + * + *

If {@code key} is provided then it takes precedence over key identifier and gets used for cryptography + * operations.

+ * + * @param key The key to be used for cryptography operations. + * @return the updated builder object. + */ + CryptographyClientBuilder key(KeyVaultKey key) {

nodes.bodyText: Seems this should either be name or ID. Since the name derives from the ID, both shouldn't be necessary.
What motivated your introduction of the AtomicReference type?
This would be more readable with a switch statement

It should just be 'key' - we leave the 'set' prefix off in builders. However, this method is package-private, so it is either Javadoc'd unnecessarily, or it should have been made public and been API reviewed, or it is only used internally and this is intentional - and should be commented as such to make that decision clear. From what I can see it is the last point - it is intended for internal use only.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -299,4 +300,18 @@ public CryptographyClientBuilder serviceVersion(CryptographyServiceVersion versi this.version = version; return this; } + + /** + * Sets the jsonWebKey to be used for cryptography operations. + * + *

If {@code key} is provided then it takes precedence over key identifier and gets used for cryptography + * operations.

+ * + * @param key The key to be used for cryptography operations. + * @return the updated builder object. + */ + CryptographyClientBuilder key(KeyVaultKey key) {

nodes.bodyText: These exceptions do not clearly state what the user should do to resolve the issue. More specificity means less confusion for end users.
Should this method be named buildAsyncKeyEncryptionKeyClient?
Good to have null checks on these helper methods.
Why do we need these empty network call records?

You probably want to store the entire KeyVaultKey so that you can validate the current time is in between notBefore expiresOn when performing encrypt, sign, and wapKey. But you could file an issue on this now and do a separate PR for it.
